pros: Flexible work environment for most departments
cons: The pay is not in line with a living wage.

pros: It earned me some money.
cons: Completely disorganized organizationally from top to bottom.

pros: Some colleagues are genuine. Don’t be fooled. None of them are in a position to change anything.
cons: The compensation is just absurdly low. There’s nothing else to say on that subject. Anyone who cares enough to try to improve things gets overworked and will be undervalued resulting in many of them leaving. There is a culture of get what you can and get out.

job_title: Director, Student Affairs in Winchester, VA
pros: Supportive colleagues—but they are not in positions to change anything
cons: Low pay, low trust, no flexibility, so much racism

review_title: Heavy teaching load, low pay, good colleagues
pros: Colleagues are great, and the students are some of the best people you'll meet.
cons: Very low pay, no opportunities for growth, high teaching load. But honestly, not any worse than other places.

job_title: Coordinator of Experiential Learning in Winchester, VA
pros: Flexibility to work from home or flex hours and the coworkers.
cons: Very low pay for staff.

review_title: Pay is as low as it gets.
pros: Nice people to work with.
cons: Compensation is poor for expectations.

review_title: Great if you want to be overworked and underappreciated
pros: free tuition after a year
cons: everything but the free college, which you still have to pay taxes on

pros:
The best part is the people.
SU is a good place to start or end your career, but it is definitely not a place for the middle. The people and community are great and they really do a great job of making you feel as if you are at home and treat you as a family (which means they pay you like family).
cons:
There are unfortunately a lot of cons to working at Shenandoah University:
-You will be paid roughly the same as minimum wage, they just make it a salary regardless of your degree level. To be honest, you probably will be making more working at places like Walmart, and Martins than at SU. 
-Little to no room for advancement.
-Absolutely no transparency, secrets are kept and only shared with a select few.
-You will be overworked.
-When people leave, they do all that they can to distribute their duties to others in that department while keeping pay the same to avoid having to hire anyone else.
-They preach diversity, but all they care about is the color of your skin as it makes them look good.
-They will not value you unless you try to leave, then at which point they will act as if you are a strong asset to them.
-Upper management does not respect staff unless you are management level).
-All of the best people leave, and the president gets angry at them for leaving without addressing the issue. Severe turnover issues.
-Massive disconnect between management, faculty, and staff. Senior management is not aware and does not recognize the amount of work that staff does. 
-The benefits used to be good, but they used Covid as an excuse to cancel a lot of them. The retirement match is now 2% and unlikely to go above that. The annual (adjustment for inflation) raise is only 1%, and with inflation always being above 1%, you are actually experiencing a decrease in salary each year.
-There is a massive issue of nepotism and favoritism. Managers will pull strings and make exceptions for their relatives who are employed or study at the university. Unless a manager really likes you, you will be treated poorly.
- They say it is 35 hours work week but is it really? 
- No appreciation from your manager or upper management. They take you for granted.
- Benefit discrimination depends on which office you work in. Other offices may get remote benefits and others get none. There are no compensatory benefits for departments that do not get what others do.
- Do NOT work in Admissions, Student Financial Services, or the Department of Public Safety,

job_title: PGY1 Pharmacy Resident in Winchester, VA
pros: Longitudinal relationships, emphasis on service and community engagement, supportive team
cons: Do not get a large variety of experiences

pros: Given the small campus size, Shenandoah University has a small community feel. Faculty and staff are eager to connect with and serve their students.
cons: Tuition is a hard sell for incoming students. Even with significant scholarship funding, private tuition is very expensive.

pros: Supportive colleagues and accessible administrators

pros: Great benefits. Depending on what department you work in you may be able to adjust your hours, have the freedom to do your job, or be micromanaged like hell.

pros: Friendly staff, family like enviornement

job_title: Program Director In Charge of 28 in Winchester, VA
pros: Great kids, food, town, excellent coaches, professors who care!
cons: Extremely high salary for president yet coaches who bring in 40% of population and still others make less than local public school teachers, sounds odd but SU seems highly female dominated with males not even considered for jobs,  Board needs stronger leadership and oversight of President,  confusing message to start year- "everyone should be grateful for a job, here is your 1% raise"-non tenured employees hear this every year, more and more part time professors, long hours

pros: Students are very motivated and involved in their community. Administration appears to really care about them on the surface. Campus is growing and there have been a lot of beautification efforts.
cons: Shared governance is an illusion. Very heavy handed management from the top down. Very little interest in hearing criticism from the faculty. Health insurance costs are outrageous compared to peer institutions. Pay is very low compared to peer institutions. Budgets are tight or non-existent. Recruiting emphasizes quantity over quality. Seems like every year working conditions and morale get worse. Very little support for faculty development.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Post, VA
pros: The campus is beautiful and right in the heart of Winchester. Your children get educational benefits and the health insurance is pretty good. You also get a lot of time off because the President is genuinely a fabulous lady.
cons: They talk a lot about caring and community, but their knowledge of how to handle people with disabilities - HR and administratively - is a joke. You're also alternatively expected (if you're upper level administration) to be everywhere at once while not going over your allotted work hours...

review_title: Shenandoah University has many outstanding academic programs, however work-life balance is a challenge.
job_title: Assistant Professor, Health Professions in Winchester, VA
pros: Excellent quality of faculty, who are innovative and excited to teach. The faculty are the highlight of my job. They are creative and invest deeply in the students and curriculum. Offices and lab facilities are newly renovated. Free, easily accessible parking.
cons: Work-life balance. Job requires working many evenings and weekends. Reimbursement and requests for funding for supplies causes tension in management. There is a patronizing environment at times, and faculty have been treated more like students than colleagues.

review_title: Great place to study if you take your education into your own hands
pros: The faculty at SU are very equipped to help in planning your success for the future as long as you put in the effort to want to work and plan with them.
cons: If you don't speak up, take initiatives, schedule one-on-ones with your professors then you will easily get lost. I've noticed that unless you aim to be seen and noticed by the staff then you will fly under the radar and graduate with little progress for the future.

pros: Shenandoah University is an amazing place to work. No matter where you look, everyone is incredibly cooperative, helpful, and inspiring. There is a huge sense of family on this campus in all areas. I'm ecstatic to be able to call Shenandoah my home.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

job_title: Assistant Director of Alumni Relations in Winchester, VA
pros: I love it here.  The atomosphere, the people, the culture its a very wonderful place to work. The benefits are great
cons: I can't live on the salary. I work other jobs to stay afloat.

review_title: Small Institute, Small Mind and the retro of the 70s
